stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the oil-rig course (internally Level 11) of Return to Yoshi’s Island, focusing on two new NPC systems: a dirt-sensitive Builder Koopa with a crying easter-egg and a WIP “Overseer Wiggler.”  He also refactors physics constants, tweaks collision, and outlines a complete warp-transition rewrite.  Throughout the session he chats with Biobak and Zeina about models/animations, discusses optimisation philosophy, and explains plans to use Only Up 64 feedback before RTYI’s release.

development_findings.summary: Only Up 64 public play-test supplied valuable data; Kaze wants to create one or two smaller hacks on the RTYI engine to polish it before the main release.
development_findings.quote: Only Up 64 was really useful play-test data and I'm gonna use the play-test data to prove RTYI… we should make like one or two more hacks on the RTYI engine before RTYI is released.

development_findings.summary: Physics tuning: reduced outer-rotate force, changed ceiling interaction so Mario bonks when diving into ceilings, removed mid-air ‘double-ceiling’ exploit, and adjusted slope handling.
development_findings.quote: I reduced the outer rotate force and I changed a lot of the physics… now you just bonk if you dive into a ceiling and there's no longer a way to get another ceiling.

development_findings.summary: Camera and memory-leak fixes are in progress; excessive conditional triangles previously caused a leak.
development_findings.quote: What's leaking memory? Too many condition triangles — so I reduced [them]…

development_findings.summary: Warp rewrite plan: during warps Mario will keep his current action while the stick is auto-held toward the warp to avoid visual freeze at 60 fps.
development_findings.quote: Instead what's gonna happen is that Mario's normal action continues while the warp is happening so it won't look weird at all because of 60fps.

development_findings.summary: Input-lag complaints traced to players switching between 60 fps (emu) and 30 fps (N64).  Full 60 fps rewrite of physics would help but is ‘not reasonable’.
development_findings.quote: Yes, we could improve input lag but I'd have to rewrite all of Mario's physics to be 60 fps — not a very reasonable thing to do.

development_findings.summary: Builder Koopa ‘cement dirt’ mechanic implemented: texture sampling algorithm checks 93 of 16,384 texels to approximate dirtiness, cutting computation ~15× and safe for N64.
development_findings.quote: We just cut computation costs into like… basically a 15th.

development_findings.summary: Threshold system: if dirtiness exceeds ~95 % (≈40 k sampled value) Koopa switches to a looping crying animation and new dialogue.
development_findings.quote: Do you want to make me cry?… if you basically make almost the entire area black, he's just gonna start crying.

development_findings.summary: Magic numbers for physics and camera moved into a single header with #defines and comments for easier iteration.
development_findings.quote: I decided I will make all the magic numbers into defines in this file and I even added comments that follow some sort of code guidelines.

development_findings.summary: Overseer Wiggler NPC concept: stands upright on oil-rig hub, reddens progressively as player sabotages four workers, then runs away; low-poly model (~693 tris) and rigs being built.
development_findings.quote: We have this oil rig… the Wiggler is gonna be right here… you mess with all four people… the Wiggler gets more red… then he runs along here and disappears.

development_findings.summary: Performance strategy: backface culling on display-list reorder (DCR) and poly-budget checks keep new effects N64-safe; actual console tests reserved for performance-critical changes.
development_findings.quote: I don't test on N64 that often — only when I make performance changes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze moved to Canada and jokes that he is ‘rich now’, but complains about high domestic shipping costs for hobby items like Yu-Gi-Oh cards.
context_findings.quote: Now that I'm living in Canada and I'm rich and all, I wanna get some Yu-Gi-Oh cards… shipping to Canada is almost as expensive as buying the damn thing.

context_findings.summary: He left Twitch due to excessive ads and now streams on YouTube, experimenting with Super Chat and considering Twitter Blue monetisation.
context_findings.quote: Twitch is just so many ads… so I decided it is time to leave.

context_findings.summary: Optimization philosophy: prides himself on N64 optimisation over general N64 hacking; dismisses SM64 PC port for not emulating true RDP features.
context_findings.quote: If I wanted my game to work on PC exclusively, I would make it in Unreal Engine.

context_findings.summary: Coding ethos: prefers self-documenting code; recently added comments but still rarely comments; sees heavy comments as unnecessary if code is clear.
context_findings.quote: They probably mean it's bad to write code in a way that comments are required — code should be self-commenting.

context_findings.summary: Emotional tone: alternates between playful banter and serious technical focus; mild frustration with tooling (Fast64 bone ordering) but ends stream satisfied with progress.

biobak.summary: Offers to help with models and gives aesthetic/UX feedback (e.g., increase dirt area, suggest service-vest for Wiggler).
biobak.quote: Let me get some point I can help you with some models since I'm a little more confident in my skills now.

biobak.summary: Advocates sampling-rate tweak and lower threshold to balance cement easter-egg difficulty.

zeina.summary: Creates animations: tasked with Builder Koopa idle flap, crying loop, and future Wiggler animations.
zeina.quote: All right, that works perfectly… So you should give him a sobbing animation for that.  Can you do that real quick? — Zeina: I can try, yeah.

zeina.summary: Coordinates asset updates (e.g., sends updated Koopa model) and flags Blender animation-loss bug.
zeina.quote: Wait, I should send you the updated Koopa… Blender has this weird thing of getting rid of animations.

key_stories.title: Using Only Up 64 to Harden the RTYI Engine
key_stories.summary: Community play-tests of Only Up 64 exposed physics and camera issues.  Kaze now plans additional small hacks on the same engine to ensure robustness before the flagship hack ships.
key_stories.challenge: Mixed reception to new RTYI physics and camera behaviours.
key_stories.process: Collected play-test data, adjusted physics constants, converted magic numbers to #defines, and scheduled extra engine stress-tests via new hacks.
key_stories.outcome: Current build feels ‘a lot better’; roadmap now includes 1-2 interim hacks for further iteration.
key_stories.key_quote: Only Up 64 was really useful play-test data… we should make like one or two more hacks on the RTYI engine before RTYI is released.

key_stories.title: Cement-Ruining Easter Egg
key_stories.summary: A builder Koopa’s fresh cement records foot-prints.  When dirtiness passes a threshold, Koopa shifts from annoyance to full sobbing, adding depth and humour.
key_stories.challenge: Detect large-area texture modification without overloading N64 CPU.
key_stories.process: Sampled 93 texels instead of all 16,384, used a running ‘dirt’ counter, set a 95 % threshold, and had Zeina animate new crying loop.
key_stories.outcome: Mechanic works in-game; performance acceptable; easter-egg likely discoverable but not accidental.
key_stories.key_quote: We just cut computation costs into like… basically a 15th.

key_stories.title: Warp Transition Overhaul
key_stories.summary: 60 fps play causes warp entry to look frozen.  Kaze sketches a fix where Mario’s action and stick input continue during transition.
key_stories.challenge: Visual stutter and perceived input-lag at higher frame-rates.
key_stories.process: Plan to auto-hold stick toward warp and continue current action; input buffer maintained.
key_stories.key_quote: Instead what's gonna happen is that Mario's normal action continues while the warp is happening so it won't look weird at all because of 60 fps.
